awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Lifetime Fluorimeter for Columbia University's Precision Biomolecular Characterization Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemical Research Instrumentation (CRIF) programs. Professor Ruben Gonzalez from Columbia University and colleagues Arthur Palmer, Colin Nuckolls and Laura Kaufman have acquired a lifetime fluorimeter.  The instrument measures the light emitted from a sample as it decays over a period of time. This is the fluorescence (decay) signal caused by irradiation of the sample by a laser.  The light emitted provides information on various properties of biochemical systems such as enzymes and proteins.  The decay signal from materials such as solar cells helps to improve their efficiency.  It provides data useful to optimize future optoelectric devices.  The instrument is being used by graduate and undergraduate students in research and in laboratory courses. It prepares the students for future careers in science, engineering and advanced education. 

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. The instrumentation is being used to study single-molecule bimolecular machines and protein folding dynamics, recognition, and catalysis.  Structural, thermodynamic, and mechanistic studies of bimolecular processes are being carried out. The excited state-dynamics of organic chromophores is being studied, and photo physical studies of conjugated polymers.  Another investigation involves the photo-physics of singlet-fission-capable organic chromophores. An investigation of the mechanisms of colloidal nanoparticle nucleation and growth is being pursued.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A lifetime fluorimeter was purchased for the Precision Biochemical Characterization Facility, which is a shared instrumentation facility in the Department of Chemistry of Columbia University that is open to all researchers. 

 

The instrument was initially installed the week of July 8, 2019.  The instrument was functional except for measuring lifetime data. This issue was resolved when engineers came back on Oct 24, 2019 for a second installation. The instrument is now working completely.

 

There have been 16 researchers who have been trained and have used the instrument to date. These users are 50% postdocs, 37.5% graduate students, and 12.5 % undergraduates. The following characterizes the demographics of the above users:  Ethnicity: 56.25% white, 25% Asian, 18.75% African American; Gender: 6.25%F, 93.75%M

 

The usage has been as follows: 26 hours (FY19), 95 hours (FY20), and 132 hours (FY21). This is less than we expected and is due to both the COVID19 shutdown and the instrument software needed to be updated to remove glitches that make it difficult for some users. This has now been corrected. Downtime has been minimal and except for the software glitches, it has been operating successfully.

 

Columbia sponsors many programs that promote teaching and bring science to a general audience and the fluorimeter will be incorporated into many of these programs. The following are only two examples. Major user Nuckolls and others have developed a successful half-day program of demonstrations and hands-on activities for 5th-7th graders through which students become energized about science. Major user Campos has organized an annual outreach program with Children’s Zone Promise Academy in Harlem to expose 7th graders to life in research laboratories. These programs target K-12 students from schools that serve communities with large populations of underrepresented groups and students who participate reflect this diversity. Each of these events has included a tour of instrumentation facilities and the fluorimeter will be included and discussed. These events have been postponed due to COVID19 but will resume in future years.

 

This fluorimeter is the only spectrometer with lifetime capabilities as well as near infrared (NIR) detection at Columbia. The fluorimeter supports the full spectrum of fluorescence methods, including steady - state emission intensity measurements, steady - state anisotropy (polarization) measurements, intensity and anisotropy lifetime measurements, and fluorescence resonance - energy transfer (FRET) measurements. It will perform fluorescence lifetime measurements over a very wide range of near - ultraviolet and visible excitation wavelengths and allow steady - state fluorescence measurements in the NIR. The fluorimeter will also be capable of performing phosphorescence measurements.

 

This instrument is essential to a wide range of research projects.  Prof. Gonzalez (PI) uses a combination of single-molecule biophysical and ensemble biophysical and biochemical methods to characterize the conformational dynamics of biomolecular machines and determine the contribution these dynamics make to biomolecular function. The proposed instrument is needed to determine the photophysical properties of fluorophores to be used in single-molecule fluorescence experiments, characterize the rotational motions and freedom of biomolecule-conjugated fluorophores used in fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) experiments, and perform fluorescence-based enzyme activity and ligand binding assays that complement single-molecule biophysical experiments. Prof. Palmer (Co-I) investigates the coupling between structure, dynamics, and function in protein folding, recognition, allostery, and catalysis. Combined with nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) experiments, fluorescence single-photon-counting polarization anisotropy decay and lifetime measurements provide unique information that is essential to these studies. Prof. Kaufman (Co-I) studies how morphology and conformation affects the photophysics of conjugated polymers at the single-molecule level. The fluorophore lifetime measurements that the proposed instrument will uniquely enable are needed to elucidate the mechanism through which the intensity of small conjugated polymers is quenched upon growth of conjugated polymer aggregates. Prof. Nuckolls (Co-I) is investigating ways of improving the efficiency of solar cells. Lifetime measurements and identification of bright states with NIR-emission would enable a deeper understanding of the photophysical properties of such materials and guide optimization their molecular structures for future optoelectronic devices.
